description: IRC/IBC code requirements, egress, fire separation, occupancy classifications

questions.question: The International Residential Code (IRC) applies to which of the following?

options.text: Detached one- and two-family dwellings and townhouses not more than three stories
All residential buildings regardless of height
Apartment buildings up to four stories

questions.explanation: Per IRC Section R101.2, the IRC applies to detached one- and two-family dwellings and townhouses not more than three stories above grade plane with a separate means of egress.

questions.question: What is the minimum width required for an egress door in a dwelling unit?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.2, egress doors shall have a minimum width of 32 inches clear opening. The 36-inch door provides this clearance when accounting for door thickness and stop.

questions.question: What is the minimum height required for an egress door opening?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.2, the minimum height of egress doors shall not be less than 6 feet 8 inches (80 inches).

questions.question: What is the maximum riser height permitted for residential stairs?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.5.1, the maximum riser height shall be 7-3/4 inches (196 mm). Risers must also be uniform within 3/8 inch of the tallest riser.

questions.question: What is the minimum tread depth for residential stairs?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.5.2, the minimum tread depth shall be 10 inches (254 mm). The tread depth is measured horizontally from the nosing of adjacent treads.

questions.question: What is the minimum headroom required over stairs?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.2, headroom shall be not less than 6 feet 8 inches (2032 mm) measured vertically from the sloped line adjoining the tread nosing.

questions.question: At what height above the walking surface are guards required?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R312.1.1, guards shall be located along open-sided walking surfaces that are located more than 30 inches measured vertically from the floor or grade below.

questions.question: What is the minimum height required for guards on residential porches and decks?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R312.1.2, guards shall not be less than 36 inches in height measured vertically from the adjacent walking surface.

questions.question: What is the maximum opening permitted in guards that would allow passage of a 4-inch sphere?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R312.1.3, required guards shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 4 inches in diameter. This prevents children from falling through or getting stuck.

questions.question: What is the required handrail height measured from the stair nosing?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.8.1, handrail height shall be not less than 34 inches and not more than 38 inches measured vertically from the stair tread nosing.

questions.question: At what number of risers are handrails required on stairs?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.8, handrails shall be provided on at least one side of stairways with four or more risers.

questions.question: What is the minimum net clear opening required for an emergency escape and rescue opening?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R310.2.1, emergency escape openings shall have a minimum net clear opening of 5.7 square feet (5.0 sq ft at grade floor). Minimum dimensions are 24 inches height and 20 inches width.

questions.question: What is the maximum sill height for an emergency escape window from the floor?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R310.2.2, the sill height of emergency escape openings shall not be more than 44 inches above the floor.

questions.question: What is the minimum width required for an emergency escape window opening?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R310.2.1, emergency escape openings shall have a minimum net clear width of 20 inches.

questions.question: What is the minimum height required for an emergency escape window opening?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R310.2.1, emergency escape openings shall have a minimum net clear height of 24 inches.

questions.question: Where are smoke alarms required in new residential construction?

options.text: In each sleeping room, outside each sleeping area, and on each story

questions.explanation: Per IRC R314.3, smoke alarms shall be installed in each sleeping room, outside each separate sleeping area, and on each additional story including basements.

questions.question: In new construction, smoke alarms must be:

options.text: Hardwired with battery backup and interconnected

questions.explanation: Per IRC R314.4, smoke alarms shall receive their primary power from the building wiring and have battery backup. When more than one is required, they shall be interconnected.

questions.question: Where are carbon monoxide alarms required?

options.text: Outside each sleeping area in dwellings with fuel-burning appliances or attached garages

questions.explanation: Per IRC R315.3, carbon monoxide alarms are required outside each separate sleeping area when the dwelling has fuel-burning appliances, attached garage, or fireplace.

questions.question: What is the minimum ceiling height required for habitable rooms?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R305.1, habitable space, hallways, and portions of basements containing these spaces shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet.

questions.question: What is the minimum ceiling height required for bathrooms?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R305.1, bathrooms, toilet rooms, and laundry rooms shall have a ceiling height of not less than 6 feet 8 inches.

questions.question: What is the minimum floor area required for a habitable room?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R304.1, habitable rooms shall have a floor area of not less than 70 square feet, with kitchens not required to meet this requirement.

questions.question: What is the minimum horizontal dimension required for a habitable room?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R304.2, habitable rooms shall be not less than 7 feet in any horizontal dimension.

questions.question: Safety glazing is required in glass adjacent to doors when the nearest vertical edge is within what distance of the door?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R308.4.2, glazing adjacent to doors requires safety glazing when the nearest exposed edge of the glazing is within 24 inches of either vertical edge of the door.

questions.question: Safety glazing is required in shower and tub enclosures when the bottom edge of the glazing is less than what height above the drain inlet?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R308.4.5, glazing in tub or shower enclosures requires safety glazing when the bottom exposed edge is less than 60 inches above the standing surface.

questions.question: What is the minimum fire-resistance rating required between a dwelling unit and an attached garage?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R302.6, the garage shall be separated from the residence by not less than 1/2-inch gypsum board or equivalent applied to the garage side.

questions.question: When a habitable room is above a garage, what ceiling protection is required?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R302.6, garages beneath habitable rooms shall have a ceiling of not less than 5/8-inch Type X gypsum board or equivalent.

questions.question: What is the minimum fire-separation distance required before exterior wall fire-resistance ratings apply?
questions.explanation: Per IRC Table R302.1, exterior walls with fire-separation distances less than 3 feet require a 1-hour fire-resistance rating on both sides.

questions.question: What is the minimum footing depth below undisturbed ground surface in areas subject to freezing?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R403.1.4, footings shall extend to a minimum of 12 inches below the undisturbed ground surface or below the frost line, whichever is deeper.

questions.question: What is the minimum compressive strength for concrete footings?
questions.explanation: Per IRC Table R402.2, concrete for footings shall have a minimum compressive strength of 2,500 psi.

questions.question: What is the minimum thickness for a concrete slab-on-ground floor?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R506.1, concrete slab-on-ground floors shall be a minimum of 3-1/2 inches thick.

questions.question: What is the minimum width for a continuous footing supporting a 2x6 wood-frame wall?
questions.explanation: Per IRC Table R403.1(1), a continuous footing for a conventional wood frame 2x6 exterior wall requires a minimum width of 15 inches for 1,500 psf soil.

questions.question: What is the minimum bearing length required for floor joists on wood or metal?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R502.6, floor joists shall have a minimum bearing of 1-1/2 inches on wood or metal.

questions.question: What is the minimum bearing length required for floor joists on masonry or concrete?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R502.6, floor joists shall have a minimum bearing of 3 inches on masonry or concrete.

questions.question: What is the maximum allowable notch depth in the end of a floor joist?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R502.8.1, notches at the ends of joists shall not exceed 1/4 the joist depth.

questions.question: What is the maximum diameter for a bored hole in a floor joist?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R502.8.1, holes bored in joists shall not be larger than 1/3 the depth of the joist and shall be at least 2 inches from the top and bottom.

questions.question: What is the standard stud spacing for load-bearing walls?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R602.3(5), studs in load-bearing walls shall be spaced not more than 16 inches on center for typical conditions.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of full-height studs required at each corner of an exterior wall?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R602.6.1, a minimum of three studs or the equivalent are required at exterior corners to provide adequate support and nailing surfaces.

questions.question: What is the maximum allowable notch in a bearing stud?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R602.6(1), notches in bearing wall studs shall not exceed 25% of the stud depth.

questions.question: What is the maximum diameter for a bored hole in a bearing stud?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R602.6(2), bored holes in bearing studs shall not exceed 40% of the stud depth.

questions.question: What is the required header size for a 4-foot opening in a load-bearing wall?
questions.explanation: Per IRC Table R602.7(1), a 4-foot span header in a load-bearing wall typically requires doubled 2x8s for common loading conditions.

questions.question: What is the minimum bearing length required for roof rafters on wood or metal?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R802.6, rafters shall have a minimum bearing of 1-1/2 inches on wood or metal.

questions.question: What is the maximum allowable notch in a rafter?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R802.7.1, notches at the ends of rafters shall not exceed 1/3 the rafter depth.

questions.question: What is the minimum size for an attic access opening?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R807.1, attic access openings shall have a minimum rough-framed opening of not less than 22 inches by 30 inches.

questions.question: When is attic access required?

options.text: When attic area exceeds 30 square feet with 30-inch headroom

questions.explanation: Per IRC R807.1, attic access is required where the attic area exceeds 30 square feet and has a vertical height of 30 inches or more.

questions.question: What is the minimum net free ventilation area required for attic ventilation?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R806.2, enclosed attics shall have cross ventilation with a minimum net free ventilation area of 1/150 of the space being ventilated.

questions.question: Under what condition can attic ventilation be reduced to 1/300 of the floor area?

options.text: When a vapor barrier is installed on the warm side

questions.explanation: Per IRC R806.2, the ratio can be reduced to 1/300 when a Class I or II vapor retarder is installed on the warm-in-winter side of the ceiling.

questions.question: What is the minimum crawl space ventilation required?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R408.2, ventilation openings for under-floor spaces shall have a net area of not less than 1/150 of the area of the space ventilated.

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance required from the ground to the bottom of floor joists in a crawl space?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R408.5, the grade in under-floor spaces shall maintain a minimum of 18 inches clearance from the bottom of floor joists.

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance from the ground to the bottom of girders in a crawl space?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R408.5, crawl spaces shall have a minimum of 12 inches clearance from the ground to the bottom of girders and beams.

questions.question: What is the minimum size for a crawl space access opening?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R408.4, access to under-floor spaces shall be through an opening not less than 18 inches by 24 inches.

questions.question: Which occupancy group covers assembly uses with 50 or more occupants?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Section 303, Group A occupancy includes assembly uses, except those classified as Group E, with an occupant load of 50 or more.

questions.question: Which occupancy group covers business offices and professional services?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Section 304, Group B occupancy includes office buildings, professional services, educational above 12th grade, and similar uses.

questions.question: Which occupancy group covers retail stores and sales rooms?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Section 309, Group M occupancy includes buildings for the display and sale of merchandise, such as retail stores, markets, and sales rooms.

questions.question: Which occupancy group covers warehouses and storage buildings?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Section 311, Group S occupancy includes buildings used for storage that are not classified as hazardous (H).

questions.question: Which occupancy group covers factories and manufacturing?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Section 306, Group F occupancy includes factory and industrial uses for manufacturing, assembling, and processing products.

questions.question: Which construction type is the most fire-resistive?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Section 602, Type I construction is the most fire-resistive with structural elements of noncombustible materials and the highest fire-resistance ratings.

questions.question: Which construction type allows combustible materials?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Section 602, Type V construction allows structural elements, exterior walls, and interior walls to be of any materials permitted by the code, including combustible.

questions.question: What is the minimum fire-resistance rating for a 1-hour fire-rated wall assembly?
questions.explanation: A 1-hour fire-rated assembly must maintain its structural integrity and prevent passage of flames for a minimum of 60 minutes when tested per ASTM E119.

questions.question: What is the maximum travel distance to an exit in an unsprinklered Group B occupancy?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1017.2, the maximum exit access travel distance for an unsprinklered Group B (business) occupancy is 200 feet.

questions.question: What is the minimum width of an exit corridor?
questions.explanation: Per IBC 1020.2, the minimum width of a corridor serving an occupant load of 50 or more shall not be less than 44 inches.

questions.question: At what occupant load are two exits required from a story?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1006.2.1, the threshold varies by occupancy. Group A requires 2 exits at 50 occupants, while Group B allows up to 49 for a single exit.

questions.question: What is the capacity per inch of stair width for egress calculation?
questions.explanation: Per IBC Table 1005.1, stairways require 0.3 inch of width per occupant served (without sprinklers) for egress capacity calculations.

questions.question: What is the maximum height for an accessible light switch above the finished floor?
questions.explanation: Per ICC A117.1 and ADA guidelines, operable controls shall be placed at a maximum height of 48 inches above the finished floor for forward or side reach.

questions.question: What is the minimum clear width for an accessible doorway?
questions.explanation: Per ICC A117.1 Section 404.2.3, doorways shall provide a clear width of not less than 32 inches measured between the face of the door and the stop.

questions.question: What is the maximum slope for an accessible route that is not a ramp?
questions.explanation: Per ICC A117.1 Section 402.2, the running slope of an accessible route shall not be steeper than 1:20 (5%). Slopes steeper than 1:20 are considered ramps.

questions.question: What is the maximum slope for an accessible ramp?
questions.explanation: Per ICC A117.1 Section 405.2, the maximum slope of a ramp shall not exceed 1:12 (8.33%).

questions.question: What is the maximum rise for a ramp run without an intermediate landing?
questions.explanation: Per ICC A117.1 Section 405.6, the rise for any ramp run shall be 30 inches maximum.

questions.question: What is the minimum clear floor space required at an accessible toilet?
questions.explanation: Per ICC A117.1 Section 604.3, clearance around a water closet shall be 60 inches minimum measured perpendicular from the side wall and 56 inches minimum perpendicular from the rear wall.

questions.question: What is the required height for an accessible grab bar at a toilet?
questions.explanation: Per ICC A117.1 Section 604.5, grab bars shall be installed 33 to 36 inches above the finished floor measured to the top of the gripping surface.

questions.question: Which of the following work typically requires a building permit?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R105.2, electrical work beyond replacement of existing fixtures typically requires a permit. Painting, cabinets, and plumbing fixture replacement are generally exempt.

questions.question: What is the typical validity period of a building permit?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R105.5, a permit becomes invalid if work is not commenced within 180 days or if work is suspended for 180 days, though jurisdictions may vary.

questions.question: Which inspection is typically required BEFORE concrete is placed for footings?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R109, footing inspection is required after excavation and before concrete placement to verify soil conditions, dimensions, and reinforcement.

questions.question: What inspection must be completed before wall covering is applied?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R109, frame inspection verifies all framing, bracing, and fire blocking before being concealed by wall covering.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a blower door test?
questions.explanation: Per IECC R402.4.1.2, the blower door test measures building envelope air leakage by pressurizing the building to 50 Pascals and measuring air changes per hour.

questions.question: What is the maximum air leakage rate for new residential construction in most climate zones?
questions.explanation: Per IECC Table R402.4.1.1, the maximum air leakage is 3 ACH50 (air changes per hour at 50 Pascals) for climate zones 3-8.

questions.question: What is the minimum slope for asphalt shingles?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R905.2.2, asphalt shingles shall be used only on roof slopes of 2:12 or greater. Between 2:12 and 4:12, double underlayment is required.

questions.question: At what slope is ice barrier required on roofs in cold climates?

options.text: Where average January temperature is 25F or less

questions.explanation: Per IRC R905.1.2, ice barriers are required in areas where the January daily average temperature is 25F or less.

questions.question: What is the minimum headlap for asphalt shingles?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R905.2.6, asphalt shingles shall have a minimum headlap of 2 inches.

questions.question: Where is flashing required?

options.text: At all intersections of walls and roofs

questions.explanation: Per IRC R903.2, flashing shall be installed at wall and roof intersections, around roof openings, at chimneys, and wherever there is a change in roof slope or direction.

questions.question: What is the minimum slope for final grade away from a foundation?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R401.3, the grade shall slope away from the foundation at a minimum of 6 inches within the first 10 feet.

questions.question: What is the minimum concrete cover for reinforcement in concrete exposed to weather?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R404.1.2.2, concrete cover for reinforcement exposed to weather shall be not less than 1-1/2 inches for #5 bars and smaller.

questions.question: What is the minimum concrete cover for reinforcement in concrete cast against earth?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R404.1.2.2, concrete cast permanently against earth requires a minimum concrete cover of 3 inches.

questions.question: What is the minimum thickness for a single-wythe concrete masonry foundation wall?
questions.explanation: Per IRC Table R404.1.1(1), the minimum thickness for a plain concrete masonry foundation wall is 8 inches.

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance required between wood siding and grade?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R317.1, wood siding shall have a minimum clearance of 6 inches from the ground.

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance required between wood structural members and grade?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R317.1, wood structural members shall have a minimum clearance of 8 inches from the ground unless approved preservative-treated wood is used.

questions.question: In areas where termite damage is very heavy, what protection is required?

options.text: Chemical treatment, physical barriers, or termite-resistant materials

questions.explanation: Per IRC R318, areas with very heavy termite infestation probability require approved methods of protection including chemical barriers, physical barriers, or naturally resistant materials.

questions.question: What is the purpose of wall bracing?

options.text: Resist lateral loads from wind and seismic forces

questions.explanation: Per IRC R602.10, wall bracing is required to resist lateral loads such as wind and seismic forces and transfer those loads to the foundation.

questions.question: What is the minimum length of braced wall panel when using structural wood panels?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R602.10.2, the minimum length of a braced wall panel using wood structural panels (Method 3) is 48 inches.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a hurricane tie or rafter tie?

options.text: Connect rafters or trusses to wall plates to resist uplift

questions.explanation: Per IRC R802.11, roof assemblies shall be designed to resist wind uplift forces. Hurricane ties provide the connection between rafters/trusses and wall plates.

questions.question: What is the minimum diameter for anchor bolts securing the sill plate to the foundation?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R403.1.6, anchor bolts shall be at least 1/2 inch in diameter and shall extend a minimum of 7 inches into the concrete or masonry.

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for anchor bolts?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R403.1.6, anchor bolts shall be spaced not more than 6 feet on center.

questions.question: What is the purpose of fireblocking?

options.text: Cut off concealed draft openings to restrict spread of fire

questions.explanation: Per IRC R302.11, fireblocking is required to cut off concealed draft openings both vertically and horizontally to prevent the movement of flame and gases.

questions.question: Where is fireblocking required in concealed wall spaces?

options.text: At ceiling and floor levels and at 10-foot intervals
Only at the top of the wall

questions.explanation: Per IRC R302.11.1, fireblocking is required in concealed stud spaces at ceiling and floor levels and at 10-foot intervals both vertically and horizontally.

questions.question: When is draftstopping required in floor-ceiling assemblies?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R302.12.1, draftstopping shall divide concealed floor-ceiling spaces into areas not exceeding 1,000 square feet.

questions.question: What type of insulation requires a thermal barrier when used in habitable spaces?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R316.4, foam plastic insulation shall be separated from interior spaces by a thermal barrier of 1/2-inch gypsum board or equivalent.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a water-resistive barrier (WRB)?

options.text: Prevent bulk water intrusion while allowing vapor transmission

questions.explanation: Per IRC R703.2, a water-resistive barrier must be installed behind exterior veneer to provide a secondary drainage plane and prevent water intrusion.

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for deck joists supporting a walking surface?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R507.5, deck joists supporting nominal 2-inch thick decking shall be spaced not more than 16 inches on center.

questions.question: What is the minimum footing size for a deck post?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R507.3.1, deck footings shall have a minimum size based on tributary load area, with most requiring at least 12-inch diameter or 12 x 12 inch footings.

questions.question: What is required when a deck is attached to a house?

options.text: Lag screws or through-bolts with proper flashing

questions.explanation: Per IRC R507.2, deck ledgers shall be attached to the band joist using lag screws or through-bolts, with proper flashing to prevent water intrusion.

questions.question: What is the minimum barrier height required around a residential swimming pool?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R4109.13, barriers surrounding pools shall be not less than 48 inches in height measured on the exterior side.

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for openings in a pool barrier?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R4109.13, openings in pool barriers shall not allow passage of a 4-inch diameter sphere.

questions.question: Where is a vapor retarder typically required in cold climates?

options.text: On the warm-in-winter side of walls
In the middle of the wall cavity

questions.explanation: Per IRC R702.7, in climate zones 5-8 (cold climates), a Class I or II vapor retarder is required on the warm-in-winter side (interior) of frame walls.

questions.question: What is the minimum thickness for gypsum board on walls?
questions.explanation: Per IRC Table R702.3.5, gypsum board applied to walls with framing spaced 16 inches on center shall be minimum 1/2-inch thick.

questions.question: What is the minimum gypsum board thickness for ceilings with 24-inch joist spacing?
questions.explanation: Per IRC Table R702.3.5, gypsum board applied perpendicular to ceiling framing at 24-inch spacing shall be minimum 5/8-inch thick.

questions.question: What is the minimum glazing area required for natural light in a habitable room?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R303.1, habitable rooms shall have aggregate glazing area of not less than 8% of the floor area of such rooms.

questions.question: What is the minimum openable area for natural ventilation in a habitable room?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R303.1, habitable rooms shall have openable area of not less than 4% of the floor area for natural ventilation.

questions.question: What exhaust rate is required for bathrooms without openable windows?
questions.explanation: Per IRC M1507.4, bathrooms without openable windows shall be provided with mechanical ventilation of not less than 50 CFM intermittent or 20 CFM continuous.

questions.question: What is the minimum width required for hallways in a dwelling?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.6, hallways shall have a minimum width of 36 inches.

questions.question: What is the minimum depth required for a landing at an exterior door?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.3.1, landings at exterior doors shall have a minimum dimension of 36 inches in the direction of travel.

questions.question: What is the maximum vertical drop from the threshold of a required egress door?

options.text: 8 inches to a landing at least 36 inches wide

questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.3.1 exception, where a landing is provided at an exterior door, the landing may be not more than 8 inches below the top of the threshold if the door does not swing over the landing.

questions.question: What is the minimum tread depth at the walk line for spiral stairs?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.10.1, spiral stairway treads shall have a minimum tread depth of 7-1/2 inches at a point 12 inches from the narrow edge.

questions.question: What is the minimum headroom required for spiral stairs?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.10.1, spiral stairways shall have a minimum headroom of 6 feet 6 inches.

questions.question: Where is lighting required for interior stairs?

options.text: Only at the top of the stairs
At the top and bottom of each flight
Only at the bottom of the stairs

questions.explanation: Per IRC R303.7, interior stairways shall have an artificial light source capable of illuminating the treads, with switches at each floor level.

questions.question: What is the minimum tread depth for winder treads at the walk line?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.5.2.1, winder treads shall have a minimum tread depth of 10 inches measured at a point 12 inches from the narrower edge.

questions.question: What is the minimum tread depth at the narrowest point for winder stairs?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.5.2.1, winder treads shall have a minimum tread depth of 6 inches at any point.

questions.question: What is the minimum clear width for residential stairs?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.1, stairways shall be not less than 36 inches in clear width above the handrail height.

questions.question: What is the maximum nosing projection on stair treads?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.5.3, nosings shall project not more than 1-1/4 inches beyond the tread below and not less than 3/4 inch.

questions.question: What is the maximum variation allowed between riser heights on the same flight?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.5.1, the greatest riser height within any flight shall not exceed the smallest by more than 3/8 inch.

questions.question: What is the required diameter for circular cross-section handrails?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.8.3, circular cross-section handrails shall have an outside diameter between 1-1/4 inches and 2 inches.

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance required between the handrail and the wall?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.8.4, the handgrip portion of handrails shall have a clearance of not less than 1-1/2 inches from the wall.

questions.question: Where are handrail extensions required?

options.text: Only at the top of the flight
At the top and bottom of the flight
Only at the bottom of the flight

questions.explanation: Per IRC R311.7.8.2, handrails shall return to the wall or terminate in a newel post, with extensions required at the top and bottom of the stair flight.

questions.question: What is the maximum triangular opening at open risers per the guard opening limitation?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R312.1.3, the triangular opening formed by the riser, tread, and bottom rail of a guard shall not allow passage of a sphere 6 inches in diameter.

questions.question: When is an emergency escape opening required in a basement?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R310.1, basements with habitable space shall have at least one emergency escape and rescue opening that opens directly to the exterior.

questions.question: What is the minimum area for a window well serving an emergency escape opening?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R310.2.3, window wells shall have a horizontal area of not less than 9 square feet, with a minimum dimension of 36 inches.

questions.question: When is a ladder required in a window well?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R310.2.3, window wells with a vertical depth greater than 44 inches shall be equipped with a ladder or steps.

questions.question: What type of door is required between a dwelling and attached garage?

options.text: Self-closing, tight-fitting solid wood or steel door

questions.explanation: Per IRC R302.5.1, doors between the dwelling and garage shall be self-closing and tight-fitting. Solid wood doors not less than 1-3/8 inch thick or steel doors are acceptable.

questions.question: Are duct openings permitted through the fire separation between a dwelling and garage?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R302.5.2, ducts in the garage and ducts penetrating the walls or ceilings separating the dwelling from the garage shall be constructed of minimum 26-gauge steel with no openings into the garage.

questions.question: What fire-resistance rating is required for townhouse separation walls?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R302.2, each townhouse shall be separated by a fire-resistance-rated wall assembly meeting the requirements for a 1-hour fire-resistance rating.

questions.question: How must townhouse separation walls be constructed at the roof?

options.text: Extend to the underside of the roof sheathing
May terminate at the attic floor

questions.explanation: Per IRC R302.2.2, fire-resistance-rated separation walls shall extend to and be tight against the underside of the roof sheathing, deck, or slab.

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance from combustible materials to a masonry fireplace opening?
questions.explanation: Per IRC R1001.11, combustible materials shall not be placed within 6 inches of a fireplace opening. This increases to 12 inches for materials projecting more than 1-1/2 inches.
